contentrichtext.text: {{For|the Space Marine chapter in the fictional background of Warhammer 40,000|Space Marines (Warhammer 40,000)}} {{Infobox Game | subtitle = | image_link = [[Image:Ultra marines cover.jpg|200px]] | image_caption = ''Ultra Marines'' box cover | designer = | manufacturer = [[Games Workshop]] | publisher = [[Games Workshop]] | illustrator = | years = <!-- years active --> | players = | ages = <!-- age range --> | setup_time = | playing_time = | random_chance = | web = | skills = | bggid = <!-- boardgame geek entry --> | bggxrefs = <!-- boardgame geek cross references for supplements etc --> | footnotes = }} '''''Ultra Marines''''' is one of a series of 4 "introductory" board games released by [[Games Workshop]] in the mid-1990s. Set in the ''[[Warhammer 40,000]]'' universe, it is effectively a 'scaled-down' version of ''[[Space Hulk]]'' and ''[[Tyranid Attack]]'', using plastic Marine Scouts from the [[Space Marines (Warhammer 40,000)|Ultramarines]], [[Space Wolves]], [[Dark Angels (Warhammer 40,000)|Dark Angels]] and [[Blood Angels]] chapters. Other components include event cards, a simple ruleset, as well as corridor and room tiles from the game ''[[Space Hulk]]''. ==Rules== Before the game begins, players arranged the interlocking room and corridor tiles on the playing area to represent a maze (a "[[Space Hulk]]"). Alien Artefact counters are randomly placed throughout the play area. Each player sets up their 5 models in a starting room of their choice and then take turns to move their pieces. The object of the game is to move the various Scout models to retrieve the artefacts and carry them to the starting rooms while stopping opponent models from achieving the same goal. Random event cards are dealt to each player that allows them to either help their own models (in the form of medipacks or double movement) or hinder opponents (by placing obstacles in their path or attacking them directly). Unlike other Games Workshop games, Ultra Marines featured a unique method of determining the accuracy of weapons fire and close combat attacks. The box of the game featured a grid printed on the inside of the lid, and dice were thrown into the lid and the results read from the squares that the dice landed in.
